content.description: This juggy climb looks more stout than it feels, with a roof at the top.  The rock is sharp but good, with great holds and fun moves.
content.location: This is the second bolt line you come to as you scramble up the hill at the base of the cliff.

content.description: This climb is short and stout, with some slab and some pump.  It has an optional 5.12a second pitch.
content.location: The first climb as you head uphill from the road.

content.description: A climb that will make your forearms feel like they are on fire.  This dude has it all; a crimpy crux (a little reach dependant), some big powerful moves and a lot of pumpy slopers to the finish.  (Jake Merg- Central mt rock)
Start left of a guano filled cave.  Pad up grey slab to steeper headwall.  Not the best climb for the grade but if you're a confident leader you will find the moves engaging.

Climb easy edges to another sea of cheese.  Great moves on big holds for the most part.  Gets pumpy at the top.  Not nearly as chossy as the name would lead you to believe.  Still some gravelly stuff on the small ledges though.
content.location: Chains to this route are 15ft up and left of the Sea of Cheese chains

content.description: Start on sharp but solid rock and climb through blocks to mud-rock above.  Rock and moves are better than it looks.  Start up the broken crack system left of Cali-Dreamin' and up and left past the Cali-Dreamin' anchors.

A wandering road of a route, the crux is definitely hanging on to moderate holds while figuring out where to go. Some of the bolts are a reach to clip due to hollow rock where you wish there was a bolt.The route looks like a nice 10 but is "deviously slopey." Overall a good climb on fun rock, and can be a different access to the 13a Devil's Highway pitch.
content.location: Just left of Devil's Highway under the pinnacle of the roof.

content.description: Unkown deets- this is a new one.

climbs.name: Irrational Exuberance
climbs.fa: Jake & Kim Mergenthaller and Randall Green

content.description: Similar to Weird Science (immediately to the looker's right), but with slightly more pumpy moves.  Somewhat sharp rock, but great positive holds.
content.location: This is the third boltline you will find as you head up the approach trail, just to the left or Weird Science.

content.description: A good name wasted on an OK climb.  Slip up an insecure start to the left of a nondescript arete:  work onto a cool diagonal crack system and continue praying for the holds to stay on as you gun for the top.  Route has two possible starts of approximately equal difficulty. (Jake Mergenthaler- Central MT Rock)
content.location: second chains from the left of the end of the main wall (below the roof, that is)

content.description: 2nd pitch of California Dreamin' (Up and left)
content.location: 2nd pitch of California Dreamin' (Up and left)

climbs.name: Hell or High Water
climbs.fa: Jeff Ho, Henry Schlotzhauer, and Whit Magro

content.description: What a radical, monster addition to this special area and wall. Hell or High Water starts on a breezy bulge, into some technical crimp-nasty goodness about 30 feet off the deck. The vertical, technical nature of this rig continues through a thoughtful and delicate crux, just below the bailout anchor, and into a long hand crack. From here, you can run it out about 30 feet to a cruxy boulder where you may just be able to clip an extended draw or plug a couple of .3"-1" cams to protect a scary whip. I only brought a couple of large nuts (see what I did there?), one of which I placed at the top of the crack with a runner, the second I placed in the obvious hole about 2/3 of the way up. Once you move into the boulder, it's on, with minimal returns on the delicate rests. However, you're coming out to a no-hands, so no big... right? WRONG! This b-boy will chew you up and spit you out for another 40 feet, offering sharp, stacking pockets and thumb-only gastons to relieve the building pump. Love!
content.protection: 18 or so bolts and various options for gear (0-4 placements, either cams or stoppers).
content.location: Obvious mega line in the middle of the right-most head wall on the Winter Wall. There is a large "X" in the center of this wall. Hell or High Water runs through the "X" and past a wide, horizontal hole about 2/3 of the way up. There is a 30-foot hand crack that runs under this hole about 20 feet, just above the midway anchor.

content.description: I'm not proud of it but it's there!  Farthest left of the wall under roof.  A bit awkward with some poor rock. (Jake Merg- Central MT Rock).  There is a short second pitch to this route pulling the overhang- 11.d
content.location: Farthest chains on the left side of the main face (below the overhang)

content.description: Up the arete/face of the right facing corner on the far left side of this wall.

Three pitches over awesome rock.

P1: 5.8 Start just left of a little "cave" and climb over some funky moves and good holds to the belay ledge. Tsunami (5.12a) goes left on the next pitch, Fatal Attraction continues right.

P2: 5.11a/b Follow the bolts up and right from the belay ledge and climb through the shallow fault line in the rock to the next anchors. Pumpy, sustained, and downright fun.

P3: 5.11b Climb up past the anchors to the left traversing seam, suss out the beta on that and it's smooth sailing to the top. Smooth does not necessarily mean easy however!

You can rap straight to the first belay ledge with a 70 and do two raps, if you have a 60 you may have to do three raps.
content.location: Between Snake Eyes and Neurotic Vulture. Start just left of a small cave. It is on the part of the wall right of the big roof.

climbs.name: Devil's Highway (13a)
climbs.fa: FA Mark Pelletier and Jack Cildress 1998  FFA Luke Evans 2003

content.description: The second pitch of Devil's Highway, climb through the apex of the roof. Very gymnastic moves with small crimps to pull over lip.
content.location: Climbs right through the pinnacle of the roof. Climb the 10a first pitch to the anchors, and good luck!

climbs.name: Devil's Highway (10a)
climbs.fa: Randall Greene, John Burbich, & Jake Mergenthaler 1998

content.description: The approach pitch to the 13a roof of Devil's Highway, it gets climbed enough separate of the roof to warrant it's own page. Find what's positive in the sea of holds and cruise to the anchors. The crux for this route is definitely figuring out just exactly what you want to use. The Devil is gonna try to confuse you and pump you out!
content.location: Directly under the 'peak' of the roof, look for the bolt line links up to the perma-draws on the 13a pitch through  the roof.

content.description: Crux is a crimpy section right before the headwall.
content.location: 2nd pitch of California Dreamin' (up and right)

content.description: Climb a sticky start to a thought-provoking crux 4 bolts up.
content.location: To find it, look for the LOWEST set of chains in this general vicinity and climb straight up to them.

content.description: Start on the left of the big cave working out onto the face for full value.  Fun climb.
